comment_body: It's interesting that the there was so much (industry) hubbub about the director of the original film (who is pretty incompetent) being replaced by a more "seasoned" director for the sequel... and now the sequel is being panned not just on its own (lack of) merits, but for being much, much worse than the original.  I can only imagine that this will validate the original director (sadly) but really means that as bad as the first book must have been, even a "seasoned" director couldn't make the second book into a movie palatable by anyone.

comment_body:
1. I donâ€™t think it would be too distracting
2. I thank him for not including her. Still a Swiftie but way past my twihard days. Happy that such a cameo is not in the Swiftverse - so to speak. 
Aside: this very much matches up with her relationship and/or pre-relationship timeline with Taylor Lautner.
author: bluesquirrel15

post_title: Chris Weisz reveals that Taylor Swift wanted to be in Twilight: New Moon but rejected her offer. He said it would be too distracting for her to appear. Do you think he was right?
comment_body:
It's not something I'd want on my resume if I was looking for more roles, but I mean, I think everybody should agree it's a step above the Hannah Montana movie, which Swift was in around the same time, in a small singing cameo. And you're right, at the time, there was in fact crossover appeal for me, and I would've eaten it up. 

> New Moon imo is the worst in the series

It depends how you mean. I think it's the most fascinatingly bad. It has the most "problematic" elements when people viewed Twilight solely as something to bash. I feel like when people mention how toxic Twilight was/is New Moon is what they're thinking of mostly whether they're conscious of it or not. And I think it's pretty interesting to watch it and dissect what they mean and how warranted it is. 

And for what it's worth? Recollecting when I was a fan, I thought Eclipse was by far more boring. It has the most love triangle shenanigans. New Moon may be "worse" but it's never boring.

post_title: Chris Weisz reveals that Taylor Swift wanted to be in Twilight: New Moon but rejected her offer. He said it would be too distracting for her to appear. Do you think he was right?
comment_body: My opinions on Eclipse and New Moon are the reverse to yours. I think New Moon is the most boring because other than establishing the love triangle, it has the least going on in the plot. I think I enjoyed Eclipse more because there was just more going on and there was a plot, a villain, a love triangle, and just a whole lot going on. Maybe too much going on? I can concede that. I still enjoy New Moon, but it's my least favourite.
author: chariotchoogle

post_title: Chris Weisz reveals that Taylor Swift wanted to be in Twilight: New Moon but rejected her offer. He said it would be too distracting for her to appear. Do you think he was right?
comment_body:
As introspective as Twilight can be, New Moon is the most introspective. Bella thrill chasing as a replacement for the high she got being with Edward is at least a semblance of an interesting idea (Simply wrong to portray that as true love, but at least a character like Jessica calls it out?), Jacob seemingly succumbing to a cult from Bella's perspective is another fragment of a good idea. 

So much mystery remained from the first film that is explained in New Moon. Even though I grew out of Twilight years ago I still think world-building and character stuff is a lot more interesting than the most memorable antagonistic threat possible or big battles or a lot of events happening, and that applies here. The first film feels downright indie and Eclipse the big budget monster the trajectory of the series was destined for and New Moon is something of a compromise between the two. 

It *is* a worse film, but it's a bad film versus a pretty boring one in its being perfectly passable entertainment for what it's going for. And I just find the former more interesting.
author: Typical_Humanoid

post_title: Chris Weisz reveals that Taylor Swift wanted to be in Twilight: New Moon but rejected her offer. He said it would be too distracting for her to appear. Do you think he was right?
comment_body: I love this idea. I must say that New Moon does pull of the depression scene well with all the seasonal changes out the window - loved that. I really enjoy the idea that New Moon was kind of a transitionary period for the franchise as it evolved from indie to blockbuster.

author: gmale9000

post_title: Twilight: New Moon drops 70% at the box office
comment_body: blockbusters or overly promoted movies like "New Moon" are predicted to have a 50% drop each week (that's expected with most movies). more than that means the movie didn't live up to expectations, and a drop less than 50% means the movie is getting good "word of mouth" and exceeded expectations.

post_title: Twilight: New Moon drops 70% at the box office
comment_body:
Yeah, it looks like it was in all of four theaters previously.

Saw it over the weekend myself. The plot is a bit silly, but the writing is absolutely superb, and the characters are fantastic. I've never read the book so I can't say if they did it justice, but it's a damn good movie regardless and I'd probably place it in my top five for the year.

post_title: AskMovies: Tempted to watch the Rifftrax version of Twilight New Moon. Does the funny outweigh the potential agony?
comment_body: Sweet. Thanks for taking one for the team sharkeybamf. I see there's at least two. Any preference? Start from the start?
author: alphabeat

post_title: AskMovies: Tempted to watch the Rifftrax version of Twilight New Moon. Does the funny outweigh the potential agony?
comment_body:
Start with the first, because it sets up a lot of recurring jokes. There are three now, if you can stand that much man-glitter. 

I love that I can directly support Mike and the gang with my money. Seeing MST3K: The Movie in a theater packed full of fans (all gasping for air from laughing so hard) on opening night was one of the highlights of my young life. My heart was broken the day that the Satellite of Love stopped broadcasting for good.

post_title:
A respected, popular and intelligent film critic 
watches Twilight: New Moon and delivers a well 
argued and positive review. I shit you not.
comment_body:
So he thinks it's good because it's about vampires, and vampire mythology has strong symbolism behind it. And it rips off Romeo and Juliet, and that's quite good. And shameless pandering to the jailbait audience is okay, because other movies shamelessly pander to teenage boys.

I'm a fan of Kermode, but I think he's stretching the limits of plausibility a little here just to stay on the same page as the average listener.
author: Shambles
